Remarks:  

1. The first continuation line is required.   
2. The second continuation line should only be entered if KIND $^{\prime=1}$ and may be repeated as many times as necessary to define all applicable elements.   
3. ICTRL, IFREQ, ICORD, KIND and AMIN apply to alltypes of matrices to be written for the subcase.   
4. Only one DMIGOUT entry can be entered per subcase. If more than one is entered, only the first encountered will be used.   
5. DMIGOUT entries may be made for each subcase desired.   
6. Marc DMIG element output willbe in files named jid.marc_dmigXX_inc where XX is shown below and inc is the increment number.  

<html><body><table><tr><td>ST</td><td>Stiffness Matrices</td></tr><tr><td>DF</td><td>Differential stiffness matrices</td></tr><tr><td>MS</td><td>Mass matrices</td></tr><tr><td>DM</td><td> Damping</td></tr><tr><td>CO</td><td>Conductivity matrices</td></tr><tr><td>SP</td><td>Specific heat matrices</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Global matrices are named jid_marc_cglsti_inc.  

7. If the SOL 600 CONTINUE options is invoked, Case Control commands and a Bulk Data include statement to receive the matrices willbeautomatically added to the original input data file. A second Nastran execution willbe spawned from the original Nastran execution after completion of the Marc execution.   
8. ID may not be 600 or 700 in the Executive Control statement, SOL 600,ID.   
9. The following Bulk Data parameters are usually required in addition to the DMIGOUT entry: \$2345678x234567890123456x34567890123456 param\* mrspawn2 nastcmd pram,mrmtxnam,KAAX param,marcfile,nastb.rc where a. nastcmd is the name of the command to run the primary and continuation jobs (examples are nastran, nast2006t1, nast2006t2, etc.) b. nastb.rc should be changed to the name of the rc file to be used for the continuation run. It usually will specify mem $\c=$ with a larger value than that of the primary run and also include a line bat $\mathbf{\bar{\rho}}=\mathbf{\rho}$ no (except for windows systems). c. PARAM,MARCFILi should not be used.   
10. For standard nonlinear static or dynamic analyses the stiffness matrix contains all contributions including the differential stiffness matrix and it is not possible to obtain the differential stiffness matrix separately. For a buckling analysis, the diffrential stiffness matrix may be obtained separately.   
11. To obtain stiffness and mass matrices for SOL 600,103, ID in field 2 of this entry must be must be zero.   
12.IfIFREQis 1 or a small number, the number of matrices output for dynamic analyses (SOL 600,109 or SOL 600,120) can be extremely large.   
13.If $\scriptstyle\mathrm{ID=0}$ , IFREQ should be 1.   
14.Setting IFREQ to a value larger than the actual number of increments in a subcase will produce no matrices.

Defines direct input matrices related to collation degrees-of-freedom (js-set)of aerodynamic mesh points for CAERO1, CAERO3, CAERO4 and CAERO5 and for the slender body elements of CAERO2. These include W2GJ, FA2J and input pressures and downwashes associated with AEPRESS and AEDW entries. The matrix is described bya single header entry and one or more column entries.Acolumn entry is required for each column with nonzero elements. For entering data for the interference elements of a CAERO2, use DMIJI or DMI.

(0 < Integer ≤ 6; blank or zero if GJ is a scalar or extra point.)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi</td><td>Grid, scalar, or extra point identification number for row index. If the matrix is rea (TIN = 1 or 2), then Bi must be blank. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

### Remarks:  

1. Matrices defined on this entry are referenced in static aeroelastic analysis by reference on AEDW and/or AEPRESS entries.In that paradigm, a single column is required. Also, DMIJ may also be used for the W2GJ and FA2J entries. Again, a single column is required. If both DMI and DMIJ are specified for W2GJ or FA2J, the DMI entry willbe used. DMI may NOT be used for AEDW and AEPRESS.   
2. The js-set DOF's for each aerodynamic theory are limited to the six-DOF paradigm (3 translations and 3 rotations). However, particular DOF's are permanently SPC'd based on the theory's ability to support those degrees-of-freedom. Unlike the DMIG entry, DMIJ data will be partitioned to the jset, not reduced.No warnings are issued about truncated data.The j-set DOF's for each aerodynamic element/grid are highly method dependent. The following data define the known set, but the j-set definition is somewhat arbitrary in the general (external aerodynamics) paradigm.  

<html><body><table><tr><td rowspan="2">Entry Type</td><td colspan="5">COMP</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>CAERO1</td><td></td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-Y</td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-Z</td><td></td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-ZY</td><td></td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

3.The header entry containing IFO, TIN and TOUT is required. Each nonnull column is started with a GJ, CJ pair. The entries for each row of that column then follow. Only nonzero terms need be entered. The terms may be input in arbitrary order. A GJ, CJ pair may be entered more than once, but the input of an element of the matrix more than once results in a fatal message.  

4. Field 3 of the header entry must contain an integer 0.  

5. For symmetric matrices (very rare in the j-set!) $\mathrm{\DeltaIFO=}6)$ , a given off-diagonal element may be input either below or above the diagonal. While upper and lower triangle terms may be mixed, a fatal message will be issued if an element is input both above and below the diagonal.  

6. The recommended format for rectangular matrices requires the use of NCOL and $\mathrm{{IFO}}=9$ . the number of columns in the matrix is NCOL. (The number of rows in all DMIJ matrices is always the js-set size--the union of the j-set and the permanently SPC'd partition). The GJ term is used for the column index. the CJ term is ignored.  

7. If NCOL is not used for rectangular matrices, two different conventions are available:  

·If $\mathrm{IFO}=9$ , GJ and CJ will determine the sorted sequence, but will otherwise be ignored; a rectangular matrix willbe generated with the columns submitted being in the 1 to N positions, where $_\mathrm{N}$ is the number of logical entries submitted (not counting the header entry). · $\mathrm{If~IFO}=2$ , the number of columns of the rectangular matrix will be equal to the index of the highest numbered nonnull column (in internal sort). Trailing null columns of the js-size matrix will be truncated.  

8. The matrix names must be unique among all DMIJ  

9. TIN should be consistent with the number of decimal digits required to read the input data adequately. For a single precision specification on a short word machine, the input willbe truncated after about eight decimal digits, even when more digits are present in a double field format. If more digits are needed, a double precision specification should be used instead. However, not that a double precision specification requires a“D" type exponent even for terms that do not need an exponent. For example, unity may be input as 1.0 in single precision, but the longer form l.oDO is required for double precision.  

10.On long word machines,almost all matrix calculations are performed in single precision and, on short word machines, in double precision. It is recommended that DMlJ matrices also follow these conventions fora balance of efficiency and reliability.The recommended value for TOUT is 0, which instructs the program to inspect the system cell that measures the machine precision at run time and sets the precision of the matrix to the same value. $\mathrm{\TOUT=0}$ allows the same DMIJ input to be used on any machine. If TOUT is contrary to the machine type specified, unreliable results may occur.  

11. If any DMIJ entry is changed or added on restart then a complete reanalysis is performed.Therefore, DMIJ entry changes or additions are not recommended on restart.

3. The header entry containing IFO, TIN and TOUT is required. Each nonnull column is started with a GJ, CJ pair. The entries for each row of that column then follow. 6. 7. If NCOL is not used for rectangular matrices,two different conventions are available:

However, not that a double precision specification requires a“D" type exponent even for terms that do not need an exponent. For example, unity may be input as 1.0 in single precision, but the longer form $1.0\mathrm{{D0}}$ is required for double precision.  

10.Onlong word machines,almost all matrix calculations are performed in single precision and, on short word machines, in double precision. It is recommended that DMlJ matrices also follow these conventions for a balance of efficiency and reliability.The recommended value for TOUT is 0, which instructs the program to inspect the system cell that measures the machine precision at run time and sets the precision of the matrix to the same value. $\mathrm{TOUT}=0$ allows the same DMIJI input to be used on any machine. If TOUT is contrary to the machine type specified, unreliable results may occur.  

11.If any DMlJ entry is changed oradded on restart then a complete reanalysis is performed.Therefore, DMIJ entry changes or additions are not recommended on restart.  

Defines direct input matrices related to physical (displacement) degrees-of-freedom (ks-set) of aerodynamic grid points.These include WKK, WTFACT and input forces asociated with AEFORCE entries.The matrix is described by a single header entry and one or more column entries.A column entry is required for each column with nonzero elements.  

Header Entry Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2 3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>DMIK</td><td>NAME</td><td>“0” IFO</td><td>TIN</td><td>TOUT</td><td>POLAR</td><td>NCOL</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Column Entry Format:  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DMIK NAME</td><td>GJ</td><td>CJ</td><td></td><td>G1</td><td>C1</td><td>A1</td><td>B1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>G2</td><td>C2</td><td>A2</td><td>B2</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>DMIK</td><td>ALPH1</td><td>0</td><td>9</td><td>2</td><td>0</td><td></td><td></td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>DMIK</td><td>ALPH1</td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td></td><td>1</td><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>2</td><td>1</td><td>1.0</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>NAME</td><td>Name of the matrix. See Remark 1. (One to eight alphanumeric characters, the first of which is alphabetic.)</td></tr><tr><td>IFO</td><td>Form of matrix being input. (Integer)</td></tr><tr><td>1 9 or 2</td><td>Square</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td> Rectangular</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Symmetric</td></tr><tr><td>TIN</td><td>Type of matrix being input: (Integer)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1 Real, single precision (One field is used per element)</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Real, double precision (One field is used per element)</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>Complex, single precision (Two fields are used per element)</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>Complex, double precision (Two fields are used per element)</td></tr><tr><td>TOUT</td><td>Type of matrix being created: (Integer)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>0 Set by precision system cell (Default)</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>Real, single precision</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Real, double precision</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>Complex, single precision</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>POLAR</td><td>4 Complex, double precision</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Input format of Ai, Bi. (Integer = blank or O indicates real, imaginary format. Integer > 0 indicated magnitude, phase format.)</td></tr><tr><td>NCOL</td><td> Number of columns in a rectangular matrix. Used only for IFO = 9. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>GJ</td><td>Grid, scalar or extra point identification number for column index. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>CJ</td><td>Component number for grid point GJ. (O < Integer ≤ 6; blank or zero if GJ is a scalar or extra point.)</td></tr><tr><td>Gi Ci</td><td>Grid, scalar, or extra point identification number for row index. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Component number for Gi for a grid point. (0 < CJ < 6; blank or zero if Gi is a scalar or extra point.)</td></tr><tr><td>Ai, Bi</td><td>Real and imaginary (or amplitude and phase) parts of a matrix element. If the matrix is real (TIN = 1 or 2), then Bi must be blank. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. Matrices defined on this entry are referenced in static aeroelastic analysis by reference on AEFORCE entries. In that paradigm, a single column is required. Also, DMIK may also be used for the WKK and WTFACT entries.Matrices defined on this entry are referenced in static aeroelastic analysis by reference on AEFORCE entries. In that paradigm, a single column is required. Also, DMIK may also be used for the WKK and WTFACT entries. If both DMI and DMIK are specified for WKK or WTFACT, the DMI entry will be used. DMI may NOT be used for AEFORCE.  

2. The ks-set DOF's for each aerodynamic theory are limited to the six-DOF paradigm (3 translations and 3 rotations). However, particular DOF's are permanently SPC'd based on the theory's ability to support those degrees-of-freedom. Unlike the DMIG entry, DMIK data will be partitioned to the kset, not reduced. No warnings are issued about truncated data. The k-set DOF's for each aerodynamic element/grid are highly method dependent. The following data define the known set, but the j-set definition is somewhat arbitrary in the general (external aerodynamics) paradigm.  

<html><body><table><tr><td rowspan="2">Entry Type</td><td colspan="5">COMP</td></tr><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>CAERO1</td><td></td><td></td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-Y</td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-Z</td><td></td><td></td><td>X</td><td></td><td>X</td></tr><tr><td>CAERO2-ZY</td><td></td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td><td>X</td></tr></table></body></html>  

3. The header entry containing IFO, TIN and TOUT is required. Each nonnullcolumn is started with a GJ, CJ pair. The entries for each row of that column then follow. Only nonzero terms need be entered. The terms may be input in arbitrary order. A GJ, CJ pair may be entered more than once, but the input of an element of the matrix more than once results in a fatal message.  

4. Field 3 of the header entry must contain an integer 0.  

5. For symmetric matrices $(\mathrm{IFO}{=}6)_{\mathrm{\Omega}}$ , a given off-diagonal element may be input either below or above the diagonal. While upper and lower triangle terms may be mixed, a fatal message willbe issued if an element is input both above and below the diagonal.  

6. The recommended format for rectangular matrices requires the use of NCOL and $\mathrm{{IFO}}=9$ .The number of columns in the matrix is NCOL.(The number of rows in all DMIK matrices is always the ks-set size--the union of the $\mathbf{k}$ -set and the permanently SPC'd partition). The GJ term is used for the column index. The CJ term is ignored.  

7. If NCOL is not used for rectangular matrices, two different conventions are available:  

·If $\mathrm{IFO}=9$ , GJ and CJ will determine the sorted sequence, but will otherwise be ignored; a rectangular matrix willbe generated with the columns submitted being in the 1 to N positions, where $_\mathrm{N}$ is the number of logical entries submitted (not counting the header entry). If $\mathrm{IFO}=2$ , the number of columns of the rectangular matrix will be equal to the index of the highest numbered nonnull column (in internal sort). Trailing null columns of the js-size matrix will be truncated.  

8. The matrix names must be unique among all DMIK.  

9. TIN should be consistent with the number of decimal digits required to read the input data adequately. For a single precision specification on a short word machine, the input willbe truncated after about eight decimal digits, even when more digits are present in a double field format. If more digits are needed, a double precision specification should be used instead. However, not that a double precision specification requires a“D" type exponent even for terms thatdo not need an exponent.For example, unity may be input as 1.0 in single precision, but the longer form 1.0D0 is required for double precision.  

10.On long word machines, almost all matrix calculations are performed in single precision and, on short word machines, in double precision. It is recommended that DMIK matrices also follow these conventions fora balance of efficiency and reliability.The recommended value for TOUT is 0, which instructs the program to inspect the system cell that measures the machine precision at run time and sets the precision of the matrix to the same value. $\mathrm{\TOUT=0}$ allows the same DMIK input to be used on any machine. If TOUT is contrary to the machine type specified, unreliable results may occur.  

11. Ifany DMIK entry is changed or added on restart then a complete reanalysis is performed.Therefore, DMIK entry changes or additions are not recommended on restart.

Remarks:  

1. Only one DOPTPRM entry is allowed in the Bulk Data Section. All defaults recommended.   
2. OPTCOD specifies which optimization code to be used in SOL 200 and METHOD specifies which optimization method to be used. The default is recommended.   
3.METHOD $\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{\Sigma}$ IJK enables a user selectable optimization strategy as documented in Vanderplaats, G. N.,ADS -- A Fortran Program for Automated Design Synthesis -- Version 1.10, NASA CR 177985,   
1985. The default is recommended.  

The I selects one of ten available strategy options:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>0</td><td>None -- Go directly to the optimizer</td></tr><tr><td>１</td><td>Sequential unconstrained minimization using the exterior penalty function method</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td> Sequential unconstrained minimization using the linear extended interior penalty</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>function method Sequential unconstrained minimization using the quadratic extended interior penalty</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>function method Sequential unconstrained minimization using the cubic extended interior penalty function</td></tr><tr><td>５</td><td>method Augmented Lagrange multiplier method</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td> Sequential linear programming</td></tr><tr><td>7</td><td>Method of centers</td></tr><tr><td>8</td><td> Sequential quadratic programming</td></tr><tr><td>９</td><td> Sequential convex programming</td></tr></table></body></html>  

The J selects one of five available optimizer options:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td> Fletcher-Reeves algorithm for unconstrained minimization</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Davidon-Fletcher-Powell (DFP) variable metric method for unconstrained minimization</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>Broydon-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) variable metric method for unconstrained minimization</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>Method of feasible directions for constrained minimization</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>Modified method of feasible directions for constrained minimization</td></tr></table></body></html>  

And K selects one of eight available one-dimensional search strategies:  

<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>Find the minimum of an unconstrained function using the Golden Section method</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Find the minimum of an unconstrained function using the Golden Section method followed by polynomial interpolation</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>Find the minimum of an unconstrained function by first finding bounds and then using the Golden Section method followed by polynomial interpolation</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>Find the minimum of an unconstrained function by polynomial interpolation/extrapolation without first finding bounds on the solution</td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td>５</td><td> Find the minimum of a constrained function using the Golden Section method</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td>Find the minimum of a constrained function using the Golden Section method followed by polynomial interpolation</td></tr><tr><td>7</td><td>Find the minimum of a constrained function by first finding bounds and then using polynomial interpolation</td></tr><tr><td>8</td><td>Find the minimum of a constrained function by polynomial interpolation/extrapolation without first finding bounds on the solution</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Defines the phase lead term θ in the equation of the dynamic loading function.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9 10</td></tr><tr><td>DPHASE</td><td>SID</td><td>P1</td><td>C1</td><td>TH1</td><td>P2</td><td>C2</td><td>TH2</td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

Example:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>DPHASE</td><td>4</td><td>21</td><td>6</td><td>2.1</td><td>8</td><td>6</td><td>7.2</td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>  

<html><body><table><tr><td> Describer</td><td>Meaning</td></tr><tr><td>SID</td><td>Identification number of DPHASE entry. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Pi</td><td>Grid, extra, or scalar point identification number. (Integer > 0)</td></tr><tr><td>Ci</td><td>Component number. (Integers 1 through 6 for grid points; zero or blank for extra or scalar points)</td></tr><tr><td>THi</td><td>Phase lead θ in degrees. (Real)</td></tr></table></body></html>  

Remarks:  

1. One or two dynamic load phase lead terms may be defined on a single entry.   
2. SID must be referenced on a RLOADi entry. Refer to the RLOAD1 or RLOAD2 entry for the formulas that define how the phase lead θ is used.   
3. A DAREA, LSEQ or static load entry should be used to define a load at Pi and Ci.   
4.In superelement analysis, DPHASE entries may only be applied to loads on points in the residual structure.   
5. RC network solver does not support DPHASE for thermal analysis.  

Defines a set of structural responses that is used in the design either as constraints or as an objective.  

Format:   


<html><body><table><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>9</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>DRESP1</td><td>ID</td><td>LABEL</td><td>RTYPE</td><td>PTYPE</td><td>REGION</td><td>ATTA</td><td>ATTB</td><td>ATT1</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ATT2</td><td>-etc.-</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></table></body></html>
